I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Socio-Economic Development Plan (SEDP) of the Government of Viet Nam for 
2006–2010 emphasizes the importance of private sector development for economic growth, 
creation of employment, income and fiscal revenue generation, and poverty reduction.1 The 
SEDP calls for development of private enterprises of all sizes as well as the removal of barriers 
to their entry and expansion. In response to the Government’s development agenda, the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) country strategy and program (CSP) for 2007–20102, as well as the 
previous CSP, envisage operations aimed at creating an environment conducive to the growth 
of private businesses in Viet Nam, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises.  
 
2.  In line with this priority, ADB has been implementing the Small and Medium-Sized 
Enterprise (SME) Development Program Loan (SDPL) cluster in partnership with the French 
Development Agency (AFD) and German development assistance through the Reconstruction 
Credit Institute (KfW).3 The SDPL’s main objective is to support the Government’s efforts to 
improve  the  business  environment  for  SMEs  in  2004–2008.  The  first  SDPL  cluster  is 
addressing: (i) establishment of a policy framework for SME development, including institutional 
coordination  mechanisms;  (ii)  reform  of  business  registration  and  licensing  systems;  and  
(iii) specific reforms to enhance SMEs’ access to land, finance, and technologies.  
 
3.  Private sector development has progressed significantly during the SDPL period. The 
World Bank’s annual doing business reports noted that the time required to complete all formal 
procedures for business start-ups dropped from 63 days in 2004 to 56 days in 2005 and to 50 
days in 2006. The number of registered enterprises increased from 122,721 in 2003 to 200,000 
by August 2006, and these businesses account for one third of the country’s manufacturing 
production. The private sector’s share of gross investment increased from 32% in 2004 to 33% 
in 2005.   
 
4.  A key outcome of the first SDPL cluster was the Government’s 5-year SME development 
plan for 2006–2010. This contains major policy actions and reforms aimed at the “creation of a 
sound policy, legal, and institutional environment that ensures fair and healthy competition for 
SMEs and service providers of all economic sectors”.4 In order to build on the achievements of 
the first cluster, the proposed project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will formulate a 
medium-term policy framework for possible ADB support of a second SDPL that will address 
reforms  during  the  remaining  period  of  the  SME  development  plan. 5  By  supporting 
implementation of the policy actions and reforms in the SME development plan and other 
reforms, the second SDPL is expected to contribute to poverty reduction by enabling inclusive

II.  ISSUES 
5.  Reforms to promote the transition to a market economy and private sector development 
have accelerated in recent years. The private sector now accounts for over 60% of gross 
domestic  product  (GDP)  and  90%  of  employment,  including  farm  households.7 The  2000 
Enterprise Law, which established citizens’ rights to launch and operate private businesses, 
significantly streamlined the enterprise registration process and led to a substantial increase in 
the number of formal enterprises. Private investment increased from 12% of GDP in 2000 to 
17% in 2005. Foreign direct investment also increased, reaching $10.2 billion in 2006.8 The 
country’s accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2007 and the implementation of 
the Unified Enterprise Law and the Common Investment Law—which are designed to ensure 
that private, state-owned, domestic, and foreign businesses are treated equally—are expected 
to stimulate private business growth further in the coming years.  
 
6.  Nevertheless, there are a relatively small number of medium-sized enterprises in Viet 
Nam. Most enterprises are large state-owned enterprises (SOEs), foreign-owned companies, 
small  domestic  household  businesses,  or  new  start-ups.  The  difficulty  that  small  domestic 
businesses have in progressing to medium-sized enterprises underscores to the need to act on 
market-oriented reforms.  
 
A.  Binding Constraints on Businesses  
1.  Access to Finance and Other Constraints  
 
7.  The latest Investment Climate Survey (ICS), conducted by the General Statistics Office 
in 2006, polled SMEs in every province on their perceptions of the main constraints to business 
development. Preliminary findings included lack of access to finance and land, uncertainty about 
regulatory policies, poor infrastructure, and the burden from taxes. Among these perceived 
constraints, access to finance has been ranked top, particularly among domestic enterprises. A 
similar finding emerged from the previous ICS, which had also illustrated that the share of 
enterprises answering the financing bottleneck as the most serious constraint was higher than 
the East Asian and global averages. 
 
8.  Access to finance is closely linked to collateral, often in the form of land use rights 
certificates and other property, and is hence related to lack of access to land. While the 2004 
Land Law established rights in relation to agricultural and residential land, it did not clearly 
address the release to the market of industrial and commercial land currently occupied by SOEs. 
The legal framework governing bankruptcy and insolvency, including the Civil Law, needs to be 
assessed as it does not appear to be facilitating the restructuring of SOEs and state-owned 
commercial banks or the release of their land and other properties for use by private businesses.

9.  The capital market is emerging as a financing source for relatively well-established 
medium-sized enterprises. However, it may not be an immediate solution to long-term financing 
needs of small and household enterprises. Apart from the Government’s efforts to establish and 
secure property rights, ongoing moves by banks to establish a private credit bureau and the 
development of the private leasing industry are more promising ways of broadening SMEs’ 
access to finance.  
 
2.  Diversity in Business Environments  
 
10.  The ICS and other surveys highlight the diverse perceptions of constraints and business-
friendliness among enterprises in different provinces. For instance, several provincial authorities 
reported that it was difficult to meet the target of completing business registration within 15 days 
and to comply with the ban on issuing licenses at the local level, both of which are important 
elements of the Enterprise Law. Implementation of reforms at the local level is another important 
aspect of private sector development.  
 
B.  Implementation of the 5-Year SME Development Plan 
 
11.  The Government’s 5-year SME development plan includes a comprehensive matrix of 
seven groups of policy actions: (i) simplifying administrative procedures to facilitate SMEs’ 
business registration, market entry, and business activities; (ii) facilitating access to land and 
production  premises  for  SMEs;  (iii)  facilitating  access  to  finance  for  SMEs;  (iv)  increasing 
competitiveness of SMEs; (v) developing a skilled labor force9 capable of supporting SME 
development; (vi) creating favorable social attitudes toward the SME sector; and (vii) managing 
implementation of the SME development plan. These groups are subdivided into 15 policy 
measures, which are in turn translated into actions assigned to specific government ministries 
and agencies. These actions are designed to be monitored against indicators and a timetable 
for their completion has been established.  
 
12.  The plan indicates the Government’s clear attempt to address constraints on business. 
Most actions have been either completed or are being implemented in partnership with ADB 
through the first SDPL cluster and with other development partners. However, implementation of 
actions scheduled for the SDPL’s final years (2008–2010) has not yet begun. Some need 
specific policy instruments and immediate policy targets to be articulated. Others may need to 
be  adjusted  on  account  of  Viet  Nam's  accession  to  the  multilateral  trading  system,  in 
accordance with the Government’s WTO action plan. A focus on private sector development in 
the context of a more competitive investment climate and greater prospects for international and 
domestic trade is needed.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The  PPTA  will  formulate  a  policy  framework  covering  2008–2010  to  improve  the 
business  environment  and  support  SME  growth.  The  framework  will  be  anchored  in  the 
Government’s 5-year SME development plan and will be based on: (i) a review of the impacts of 
the first SDPL cluster, and (ii) an assessment of constraints to private enterprise growth. On the 
basis of this analysis, a prioritized plan of action will be incorporated into the second SDPL’s

design.  The  plan  of  action  will  continue  the  first  SDPL’s  focus  on  business  environment 
improvement as opposed to targeted support to SMEs.10  
 
14.  First SDPL Cluster Assessment and Validation of Continued Support. The PPTA 
will review the development impacts of the first SDPL’s reforms. Several issues covered in the 
Government’s 5-year SME development plan and identified as constraints in the ICSs were 
addressed under the first SDPL: property rights were improved, including land registration and 
secured  transactions;  accounting  reforms  were  carried  out;  and  the  leasing  sector  was 
strengthened. The effectiveness of these reforms will be reviewed.  
 
15.  Articulation of Policy Instruments to Address Binding Constraints. The PPTA will 
carry out a further analysis of the private sector growth constraints identified in the ICS. A 
decision tree analysis will be undertaken to articulate sound policy measures to remove or 
alleviate  key  obstacles.  The  analysis  will  be  undertaken  in  close  consultation  with  the 
Government, private sector entities, and development partners. Efforts will be made to ensure 
that stakeholder consultations and surveys reflect broad perspectives on economy-wide benefits 
as opposed to the narrow interests of segments of the business community. The PPTA will also 
identify  measures  to  enhance  gains  from  trade,  such  as  trade  facilitation,11 as  well  as 
implementation of the Government’s WTO action plan. 
16.  Review of the 5-Year SME Development Plan. The PPTA will review the policy actions 
in the Government’s 5-year SME development plan for 2006–2010, focusing on (i) business 
registrations and post-registration management, (ii) business-related legislation, (iii) property 
rights, (iv) accounting and financial reporting, (v) taxation and related regulations, (vi) technical 
regulation and standards, and (vii) management of the SME development plan’s implementation. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  The PPTA activities will focus on preparing a medium-term policy framework for private 
sector development. Consultants with expertise in private sector development and related 
areas  will  work  with  government  counterparts  and  other  stakeholders  during  organized 
discussions. Consultations may also occur through conferences or seminars on key policy 
issues. 
 
18.  Consultants will also maintain close contact with development partners represented in 
Hanoi-based SME working group meetings. Feedback from the private sector will include 
participation in key events and conferences, including the Viet Nam Business Forum. When 
required,  consultants  will  directly  engage  a  competent  research  institute  or  a  business 
association to undertake supplementary surveys on business development constraints.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, of which ADB will provide 
$500,000. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government of Japan. The Government will finance the remaining $125,000 equivalent through 
counterpart staff, office space, administrative services, and physical facilities. The Government 
has been informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
The cost estimates are in Appendix 3.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  To facilitate implementation of the PPTA, the existing SDPL steering committee will 
oversee its implementation. The committee is headed by the vice minister of the Ministry of 
Planning and Investment, which is designated as the Executing Agency.12 The implementing 
agencies include the Ministry of Finance, Ministry of Industry and Trade, Ministry of Justice, 
Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment, Ministry of Science and Technology, and the 
State Bank of Vietnam.  
 
21.  The PPTA will be implemented over a 22-month period from March 2008 to December 
2009. Over the course of its implementation, 10 person-months of international consultants and 
12  person-months  of  national  consultants  will  be  required.  Consultants  will  be  recruited 
intermittently  on  an  individual  basis,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  (2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  While  the  international  private  sector 
development  specialist will  coordinate  field  work  by  other  consultants,  ADB’s  project  team 
leader will directly lead policy dialogues with the Government based on the consultants’ outputs. 
The consultant team will produce inception, interim, draft final, and final reports. The final report, 
incorporating comments from the Government and ADB, will be submitted when the team of 
consultants completes its services. Terms of reference are outlined in Appendix 4. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for preparing the Second Small and Medium-Sized Enterprise 
Development Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy, and the sector analysis, describe 
how the project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty 
reduction strategy of the partner country. 
The SEDP of the Government of Viet Nam for 2006–2010 emphasizes the importance of private sector development for 
economic growth, creation of employment, income and fiscal revenue generation, and poverty reduction. The SEDP 
calls for the development of private enterprises of all sizes and removal of barriers to their business entry and expansion. 
In response to the Government’s development agenda, a series of CSPs since 2002 envisaged operations aimed at 
creating a business-enabling environment conducive to growth of private enterprises, particularly those of small and 
medium sizes. In particular, the poverty assessment in the latest CSP for 2007–2010 endorsed the contribution of 
economic growth to poverty reduction, with particular attention to roles of SMEs and associated job creation in the 
industry and service sectors.1  
 
 
The second SDPL will support the Government’s initiatives to create a more enabling business environment, such as 
implementation of the Unified Enterprise Law aimed at reform in registration and licensing procedures. In the medium 
term, resulting competition among enterprises is expected to stimulate the economy’s overall productivity, raising the 
potential growth rate. A rise in business start-ups may also create new employment opportunities. Since the early 1990s, 
sustained overall economic growth and private sector-led employment generation have actually been major contributors 
to a sharp decline in poverty in Viet Nam, where a strong correlation has been empirically observed between a rise in 
per capita gross domestic product and poverty reduction, and the second SDPL will help sustain this trend from the 
business environment perspective.2  
B.  Targeting Classification 
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, 
etc.) 
2.  Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
The SDPL reduces poverty in an indirect manner through creation of a more enabling business environment that may 
contribute to pro-poor growth, social development, and good governance.   
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
Special attention will be paid to possible impacts on SMEs representing the poor in the broader business community. 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? 
The second SDPL is not a targeted intervention. At the initial poverty and social analysis stage, no specific indigenous 
persons, gender, relocation, or other social issues have been identified. A summary poverty reduction and social 
strategy will be prepared.

3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-
poor governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
While the second SDPL does not accord targeted preferential support to any specific business entity, regardless of its 
size and ownership, its approach aimed at broad-based improvement of Viet Nam’s business environment should entail 
a potential for pro-poor growth, as evidenced by several empirical cross-country studies. For instance, relatively 
business-friendly countries are achieving a higher level of human development.3 Surveys conducted among the poor in 
50  countries  reveal  that  a  majority  perceives  starting  a  business  as  an  effective  way  out  of  poverty,  and  the 
unemployment rate is lower in countries where doing business is less difficult.4 
II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the project? 
Through facilitating Viet Nam’s transition to a market economy, the SDPL will introduce wider choices and more 
competitive prices to consumers and will enable more efficient utilization of the country’s production capacity through 
improved resource allocation. Both combined will enhance static economic welfare. In the medium term, there could be 
dynamic gains of improved productivity that may be stimulated through enterprises’ exposure to competition and ease of 
business—as confirmed by cross-country evidence showing that there is a positive correlation between ease in 
procedures to start up a business and productivity5—and resulting contribution to economic growth. As such, while the 
initial gains will accrue to consumers and producers who can take immediate advantage of market competition, the rest 
of the economy is also expected to become better off in the medium to long term, depending on the pace of price 
adjustments and reallocation of factors of production.  
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
Perfect information is a prerequisite for any beneficiary—both consumers and producers—to gain from the improved 
business environment.  
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? 
Potential constraints on accessing the proposed benefits include policy-induced rigidity in factor markets, prices, and 
asymmetric information, all of which will be reviewed in the course of the second SDPL’s preparation.  
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1.  Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
Business enterprises operating in Viet Nam 
2.  What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., 
workshops, community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based 
organizations, etc.)? 
Collective consultation with the business associations representing enterprises operating in Viet Nam, such as the Viet 
Nam Chamber of Commerce and Industry. ADB has also been actively participating in the Viet Nam Business Forum, 
and will maintain close contact with the secretariat.  
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
  Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
4.  Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain.  
ADB has already started stakeholder consultations with the Viet Nam Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Viet Nam 
Business Forum, and other business circles through fact-finding for the PPTA and during other occasions under the 
SDPL framework that are planned to be undertaken continuously at the stage of the second SDPL’s formulation.

C.  Gender and Development 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
The proposed design of the second SDPL’s subprogram indicates that there will be no negative impact on women.  
 
2.  Does the proposed project/program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s 
empowerment by improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and 
participation in decision making?       Yes          No    Please explain.  
The second SDPL is aimed at establishing an equal environment for all enterprises, as opposed to provision of targeted 
support to any commercial entities.  
3.  Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or to widen gender inequality? 
          Yes          No    Please explain.  
The second SDPL is aimed at establishing a nondiscriminatory environment for all enterprises.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS1 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Private Sector Development Specialist (4 person-months) 
 
1.  The  private  sector  development  specialist  will  have  a  policy-oriented  background  in 
enabling  business  environments  for  enterprise  development.  Under  guidance  from  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  project  team  leader,  the  private  sector  development  specialist  will 
coordinate outputs from the consultant team with regard to formulation of the second Small and 
Medium-Sized Enterprise Development Program Loan (SDPL) and conduct a capacity-building 
needs assessment. Specific tasks will include the following.  
 
(i)  undertake a diagnostic analysis of private enterprise growth constraints in Viet Nam 
by reviewing the Investment Climate Survey and other existing research works and 
conducting  supplementary  surveys  and  hearings  with  the  business  community 
through outsourcing to a competent research institute or a business association 
through direct engagement;2 
(ii)  study government strategies for private sector development, including the 5-year 
small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) development plan for 2006–2010, Decree 
90 on SME development, World Trade Organization (WTO) action plan, Unified 
Enterprise  Law,  Common  Investment  Law,  and  their  implementation  decrees, 
among others; 
(iii)  assess development impacts of the first SDPL cluster’s reforms, and validate areas 
that require continued policy dialogues in the period leading up to 2010; 
(iv)  assess the status of decentralization and implementation of Unified Enterprise Law, 
Common  Investment  Law,  and  other  regulatory  reforms  and  taxation  at  the 
provincial level, and create possible improvement measures; 
(v)  based on findings from the above-mentioned activities, articulate possible policy 
instruments to facilitate private sector development, and undertake prioritization, 
sequencing,  and  elaboration  of  necessary  reform  measures  in  the  form  of  a 
medium-term policy framework proposal; 
(vi)  confirm validity of the cluster approach as the modality of the second SDPL; 
(vii)  review related development assistance projects and programs with a view to avoid 
direct duplication of these with the second SDPL; 
(viii)  analyze possible poverty, social, gender, and environmental impacts; 
(ix)  conduct stakeholder consultations with the Government, business community, and 
donors; 
(x)  prepare overall inputs for a draft second SDPL proposal, including its rationale and 
scope; updated sector assessment and a decision tree analysis; a road map for the 
design and implementation of prioritized reform measures, i.e., a summary of the 
medium-term policy framework; development coordination matrix; and social and 
poverty impact assessments; 
(xi)  support  initiatives  for  donor  coordination  on  private  sector  development  and 
executing  partnership  with  the  Viet  Nam  Business  Forum,  through  the  SME 
promotion working group and other channels, and in consultation with the Ministry of

2  The cost for a supplementary survey package is expected to be below $10,000.

Appendix 4  13 
Planning  and  Investment,  ADB’s  Viet  Nam  Resident  Mission,  the  International 
Finance Corporation, the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, and 
other development partners; 
(xii)  conduct a related capacity-building needs assessment of the Government; and 
(xiii)  assist ADB missions with related activities, as required. 
 
2.  Financial Intermediation Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
2.  The financial intermediation specialist will have a background in finance-related issues. 
Specific tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  conduct a diagnostic review of regulatory regimes and proposed reform initiatives 
directly or indirectly related to access to finance by business enterprises, including 
the new/draft regulation on non-banking credit institutions, current/prospective Law 
on  Credit  Institutions,  Civil  Law,  and  the  legal  framework  for  bankruptcy  and 
insolvency, among others; 
(ii)  explore possible options to improve the business environment for enabling market-
based financial instruments to alleviate/remove obstacles to enterprises’ access to 
finance, such as private leasing; sales of receivables; factoring; private guarantees; 
credit information bureau(s); debt recovery services; property valuation; credibility 
assessment; and reform measures in other related areas, such as property rights 
and secured transactions, bankruptcy, insolvency, accounting, and taxation; 
(iii)  address issues related to enterprises’ access to finance reflected in Viet Nam’s 
terms  of  WTO  accession,  including  market  access  and  national  treatment 
commitments  under  the  General  Agreement  on  Trade  in  Services  and 
multilateral/regional trade agreements; and 
(iv)  propose policy instruments and their time-bound implementation arrangements that 
could be considered as part of the second SDPL, avoiding duplication with other 
policy-based assistance by ADB and development partners, and provide technical 
policy advice to the proper government authority. 
 
3.  Customs Modernization and Trade Facilitation Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
3.  The customs modernization and trade facilitation specialist will have a background in policy-
related issues of cross-border trade. Specific tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  evaluate completed, ongoing, and prospective initiatives and legislation for customs 
modernization and trade facilitation with a view to guide the Government with its 
implementation  of  relevant  international  rules,  including  the  World  Customs 
Organization’s  Framework  of  Standards  to  Secure  and  Facilitate  Global  Trade, 
Revised  Kyoto  Convention,  WTO’s  Customs  Valuation  Agreement,  related 
provisions from the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Articles V, VII, VIII, 
and X), and the Cross-Border Transport Agreement under the Greater Mekong 
Subregion  Economic  Cooperation  Program,  among  others,  with  reference  to 
existing studies and research works (e.g., World Customs Organization’s diagnostic 
assessment); 
(ii)  conduct a supplementary assessment on customs clearance time and costs to 
traders in relation to cross-border trade to build upon existing relevant studies (e.g., 
World Bank’s annual doing business reports);

14  Appendix 4 
 
(iii)  review development assistance provided in the area of customs modernization and 
trade facilitation by multilateral and bilateral development partners; 
(iv)  propose  policy  instruments  with  supporting  assessments  and  their  time-bound 
implementation  arrangements  for  customs  modernization,  trade  facilitation,  and 
other trade policy issues that could be considered as part of the second SDPL, 
avoiding duplication with other policy-based assistance by ADB and development 
partners  while  exploring  synergy  with  related  trade  and  transport  facilitation 
initiatives under the Greater Mekong Subregion program; and 
(v)  consult  with  government  counterparts,  and  provide  necessary  technical  advice, 
particularly on implementation of key international rules and practices (e.g., use of 
risk management). 
 
4.  Economist  (Domestic  Factor  Markets  and  Trade-Related  Adjustment)  (2 
person-months) 
 
4.  The economist will have a background in microeconomics, international economics, and/or 
related disciplines, and will review any constraints and policy-induced rigidity on domestic factor 
markets (both labor and capital) that prevent fuller utilization of resources and capacity, with a view 
to facilitating growth of private enterprises and inter-industry/intra-industry adjustment following 
trade liberalization. Specific tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  provide policy advice on further improvements to opening and closing businesses 
with regard to registration, bankruptcy, and licensing processes, on account of their 
cost-benefit and feasibility for implementation; 
(ii)  identify potential constraints on the labor market and flexible allocation of human 
resources; 
(iii)  explore opportunities for further improvements to property rights, both in their own 
right and as a way to remove constraints to access and inter-industry/ intra-industry 
shift of factors of production; 
(iv)  review business-related taxation and its implementation from the perspective of 
minimizing distortions to efficient domestic resource allocations;  
(v)  based  on  the  above-mentioned  tasks,  create  recommendations  on  a  holistic 
approach to ease growth of small enterprises; and 
(vi)  review progresses in reforms related to implementation of multilateral and regional 
trade agreements and commitments, and identify measures that may be required to 
capture  domestic  efficiency  gains  from  WTO  accession  and  further  trade 
liberalization. 
 
B.  National Consultant 
1.  Business Environment Specialist (12 person-months)  
 
5.  The business environment specialist will have a background in enterprise development, 
understand key policy issues related to private sector development, and be proficient in English. 
The business environment specialist will be responsible for providing inputs related to the overall 
second  SDPL’s  preparation,  especially  in  legal  and  policy  reform  areas,  among  others.  The 
specialist will undertake the following tasks:

Appendix 4  15 
(i)  provide assistance to international consultants in all aspects of their tasks within the 
terms of reference, including in-country support for donor coordination and liaising 
with the Viet Nam Business Forum; 
(ii)  under the guidance of international consultants, collect and analyze information, and 
make it available in English in an organized and readable form; 
(iii)  conduct  research  on  specific  topics  as  required  by  ADB  and  international 
consultants; 
(iv)  arrange and organize discussions as required, and assist ADB and international 
consultants  in  preparing  materials,  including  translation  of  documents  and 
interpretation of discussions;  
(v)  provide administrative and logistic support to ADB missions and the Government for 
SDPL management; and 
(vi)  closely coordinate with the Government on SDPL management, and maintain close 
contact on a regular basis.
